items.title: 039 - Are you a Solopreneur or a Teampreneur?
items.content_text: What kind of entrepreneur are you? Do you want to be like a solo artist, or do you want to be part of a band?
items.content_html:
What kind of entrepreneur are you? Do you want to be like a solo artist, or do you want to be part of a band?

Show notes

  • Marketing for Developers re-launches on Oct. 15, 2016!
  • Product People Club
  • Nathan Barry interview
  • I started my first business when I was 18. Here's my business card.
  • What kind of business do you want to run? Reach out on Twitter, Instagram, or Snapchat (I'm mijustin on all of those)
  • What happened to Network Effects and Remote Workers Club?
  • You want more than product / market fit
  • The Mega Maker Mob is working!
  • Music by Striker-Metal.com
  • Podcast hosting by Simplecast.fm

Advice for Solopreneurs

  1. Find community: find a community both online and offline. For me that's Product People Club and Cowork Vernon.
  2. Get accountability: for me, I have a weekly mastermind meeting. Basically it's a regular accountability meeting (you usually with 2-3 other people).
  3. Don't waste time, resources, or opportunity: as a solo person, you can't afford to waste anything. Don't fool around! Focus on one project at a time, and build it until you launch it. Double down on what's working.
  4. Use the right tools: after trying out everything, I think Coach is the perfect platform for solopreneurs. Check out my page on coach here: justinjackson.withcoach.com
items.summary: What kind of entrepreneur are you? Do you want to be like a solo artist, or do you want to be part of a band?

items.title: 038 - What motivates people to buy?
items.content_text: Learn how to make things that people actually want. Justin is joined by author Alan Klement to talk about the "Jobs to be Done" framework .
items.content_html:
Learn how to make things that people actually want. Justin is joined by author Alan Klement to talk about the "Jobs to be Done" framework .

Don't define your competition by features or product. Rather you need to define your competition by what helps customers make progress.

Show notes

  • Are you a software developer who wants to launch your own product? The updated Marketing for Developers course launches on Oct. 15, 2016
  • When Kale and Coffee Compete a book by Alan Klement
  • Product People Club
  • Jobs to be Done on Medium
  • Canva.com

"If there's a picture in our minds of how we want life to be, and we're not quite there, we want to make progress towards that vision."

There's two things that cause people to switch products:

  1. The picture in your mind (of how you want things to be) has changed.
  2. The solution you're using is no longer delivering you progress.
items.summary: Learn how to make things that people actually want. Justin is joined by author Alan Klement to talk about the "Jobs to be Done" framework .

items.title: 037 - Find and validate good product ideas
items.content_text: After a long hiatus, Justin is back to talk about a system for discovering what people want, and building solutions they'll actually buy.
items.content_html:
After a long hiatus, Justin is back to talk about a system for discovering what people want, and building solutions they'll actually buy.

Show notes

  • A few Product People Club spots left!
  • Feeling dizzy
  • Mega Wednesday - live video at 10am every week
  • Alen Klement's new JTBD book
  • Like2Have.It

The reason people buy a product is they imagine their lives better with that product, than without it.

Steps for discover product ideas.

Download the slides here.

1. Start with people

Choose an audience that...

  1. You know, understand, and like
  2. That buys things
  3. That congregates online

What group is already paying you for your time and expertise?

2. Research + listen

Places to do research online:

  1. Google (look at related keywords)
  2. Twitter
  3. Reddit
  4. Facebook Groups
  5. Facebook search

3. Create a hypothesis

As a math grad student I want an online course so that I can make it through my first year of grad school.

4. Test your hypothesis

What's the smallest "product" you could create that could disprove your hypothesis?

What you learn when you launch a tiny version:

  1. How hard is it to find customers?
  2. Did I hit a nerve? Did I identify the #1 pain?
  3. How hard is it to get people to pay?
  4. How satisfied were people with the solution?
  5. Do I like the customers?
items.summary: After a long hiatus, Justin is back to talk about a system for discovering what people want, and building solutions they'll actually buy.

You might be pursuing someone else's path to success. We try to reverse engineer it, and apply it to our own life. It doesn't work! Forge your own path. Trust in your own ability to make good decisions.

Doing stuff is your best education. Hypotheticals are the enemy. Get out and test your assumptions!

Take a nap.

Today instead of talking about Balsamiq Mockups (the product), I would like to tell you a bit more about Balsamiq (the company). My friend Peldi started it back in 2008 as a solo founder: totally bootstrapped, doing everything himself. The product was immediately successful and Peldi was forced to hire people and grow the company. In the 8 years since, Balsamiq has become the undisputed leader in their space and also a very inspiring company to follow. They still haven’t taken any outside investment, and have 21 employees now, all geographically distributed. On their “Life @ Balsamiq” blog they share a lot of their very progressive company policies and everything else they learn along the way (including revenue numbers every year!). In this episode: why your "thing" needs to be in people's top 3.
items.content_html:
Why don't people care about what you've made?

In this episode: why your "thing" needs to be in people's top 3.

What is this show about? Who is it for?

Justin is making 100 things in 2016. Some of the projects are just for fun; and others are so he can make a living.

Really, this show is a lot about exploring the tension between living a creative life, while also making a living.

Everybody has a top 3

You probably have 3 apps on your phone that you use 80% of the time.

Unless you can get into someone's top 3, it's going to be difficult for them to really connect with that thing you've made.

Sponsor: Balsamiq.com

items.content_html:

  1. Figure out what people want.
  2. Create things that are well-made.
  3. Be unique, surprising, and unexpected.
  4. Keep shipping more stuff.
  5. Be persistent and adaptable.

items.title: The guts to be original
items.content_text:
We want to make stuff. We want to live a creative life while still making a living.

What's the best path to achieve that dream?
items.content_html:
We want to make stuff. We want to live a creative life while still making a living.

What's the best path to achieve that dream?

So often we try to follow those that have gone before us. But if you've tried that, you know it doesn't work. To succeed, we really need to forge our own path.

  1. Our success is going to look different than those that have gone before us.
  2. Finding success is messy.
  3. The way to find success is to be unique; to do things differently than they've done before.

Once you give up this idea that the path is set for you, it becomes freeing. Now you know it's up to you. You have the autonomy and the freedom to find your own way.

Show notes

  • Kevin Kelly at XOXO 2014
  • Social SMS experiment #3
  • Usborne Spy Handbook
  • Podcasts are trying lofts of different business models (Gimlet's here, RelayFM here)

Today's launch: a Secret Club for Makers

The idea for us to have an outlet: to escape the monotony of serious work, and make fun things together.

  • You'll get a weekly maker mission (like this and this and this). It's like going on a creative coffee break.
  • You'll get access to member profiles. Connect & collaborate with other makers from all over the world.
  • You'll get secret maker society swag in the mail. This includes the exclusive SMS badge and stickers.
  • Plus tons of other goodies I can't talk about now.

Have fun. Get help launching your serious projects.

Want to be a part of the beta? There's 10 spots available.

Go to: megamaker.co/secret

Striker-metal.com for our theme music (get Bad Decisions here). Simplecast.fm for podcast hosting + stats.

items.title: Let's get weird
items.content_text:
Justin texts 150 strangers, and reveals how they replied.

Perfectionism can be restrictive. It can hold us back from experimenting, or putting out more work.

Makers need to get weird.
items.content_html:
The biggest risk to creative work is curated perfectionism. It's happening in music, art, film, and on the web. Everyone wants a flawless portfolio and will only publish perfect work.

The challenge is that perfectionism can be restrictive. It can hold us back from experimenting, or putting out more work.

To make better stuff, we're going to need to get weird.

In this episode Justin talks about texting 150 strangers, and reveals how they replied.

items.title: I walk the line
items.content_text:
Creative work, by it's very nature is divisive. Our work can't be for everybody, but still has to appeal to some people.

In this episode we explore this tension of being authentic without being alienating. This is also the last episode in our "self-publishing a book" series.

Creative work, by it's very nature is divisive. Our work can't be for everybody, but still has to appeal to some people.

In this episode we explore this tension of being authentic without being alienating. This is also the last episode in our "self-publishing a book" series.

items.title: Can we run a warehouse out of our garage?
items.content_text:
The general consensus is that authors don't make much money.

But in 2012, a young designer found a better way.
items.content_html:
The general consensus is that authors don't make much money:

"My novel, “Broken Piano for President,” shot to the top of the best-seller lists. This is what it’s like, financially, to have the indie book publicity story of the year and be near the top of the bestseller list. Drum roll. $12,000." — Patrick Wensick

But in 2012, a young designer named Nathan Barry figured out a better way. He realized that by teaching people something valuable, and self-publishing himself, he could earn more as an author. (You can listen to Part 1 and Part 2 of the 2013 interview here)

"Quantity produces quality. If you only write a few things, you’re doomed." — Ray Bradbury

This week on the show we'll be exploring the world of writing and self-publishing.

(You can see the book I'm working on here)

Sarah's rules about living a creative life:

  1. It's always worth pursuing the things you love.
  2. Sometimes you're going to have to get creative about how the money works

  • 29% ordered a Men's large

items.title: Automated t-shirt deployment
items.content_text:
In this episode, we launch our own custom t-shirt brand.

Learn how to create your own t-shirt store, without spending thousands of dollars.
items.content_html:
In this episode, we launch our own custom t-shirt brand.

Learn how to create your own t-shirt store, without spending thousands of dollars.

You can now order the MegaMaker t-shirt online! Use the code PODCAST and get $5 off your order!

How to make your own t-shirt brand

  1. Start with great artwork
  2. Choose a high quality garment
  3. Go to theprintful.com. They do print-on-demand t-shirts.
  4. Create a t-shirt using their tools. (Remember, logo placement is important)
  5. You can order t-shirt samples directly from theprintful.com
  6. When you receive the samples, look for 3 things: How does the logo look and garment feel? How well does it go through the wash & dry cycles? How do people react to the shirt when you wear it?
  7. Gather online feedback: post photos of you wearing the shirt on Instagram, Facebook, etc...
  8. You can also consider using crowdfunding platforms like Teespring and Cotton Bureau
  9. Your first production run: I recommend using theprintful.com. They'll do print on demand for every order that comes in. They'll also package and ship it for you. This means you don't need to hold inventory.
  10. Create your online store: I used WooCommerce for the MegaMaker store. You can also use Shopify. Using these platforms, whenever people order an item, it will automatically generate an order in Printful.
  11. What happens next? We'll find out!

Are you going to sacrifice quality so you can increase your margins?

I'll report back on Wednesday with sales numbers.

Today is the official launch of the MegaMaker store

"When can I order a MegaMaker t-shirt? I want one!"

Right now! Go to store.megamaker.co. We're launching with a low price: $25 per shirt. Even better, use the coupon PODCAST and get $5 off your order!

items.title: What makes a great shirt?
items.content_text:
Millions of shirts are made every year; but how can we make t-shirts that people actually want to wear?

Learn how to make your own t-shirts, and watch Justin as he launches his own t-shirt brand.
items.content_html:
Millions of shirts are made every year; but how can we make t-shirts that people actually want to wear?

Learn how to make your own t-shirts, and watch Justin as he launches his own t-shirt brand.

First three steps to making great shirts

  1. Great artwork - you need to have something compelling on the shirt. Whether it's your logo or artwork, make sure it's something people want to wear on their chest.
  2. Choose a high quality garment - cheap shirts feel cheap. They shrink over time, the cut looks funny, and the fabric feels itchy. Get something that feels good.
  3. Artwork placement is important - consider where you're putting your artwork! Especially on women's shirts.

Check back on Saturday for the next steps: printing (ink) type, how to order samples, how to get feedback, how to do production runs.

Justin kicks off the weekly maker challenge. What's he's going to try to make in 7 days?

If this podcast was Star Wars, the first two episodes would be "A New Hope" and this episode would be "Empire."

Start with something small and silly.

Update: MegaMaker just landed in iTunes! Please help by leaving a 5 start review at megamaker.co/review

This week's MegaMaker project: a burrito

Justin's goal this week is to make something that is both small and ridiculous. A burrito. Why?

  • Burritos are freakin' delicious.
  • I suck at cooking and wanted a challenge.
  • I love burritos.

Why not take the pressure off ourselves, and create something just because it's fun?

Who sponsored my burrito?

I want to thanks these guys for believing in me. They were willing to take a chance on a crazy idea. Please give them your business!

The new year is here. How can you make this year better than the last? For Justin the answer is to make 100 things.

MegaMaker is a podcast for people who want to consume less and make more.

It doesn't matter if you swing hammers, a keyboard and mouse, a paintbrush, a needle and thread, or a soldering iron. We're all makers here.
